716721f-a.title: Manhattan: Bond Street - Lafayette Street
716721f-a.text:
11 Bond Street, at the S. W. corner of Lafayette Street.
This structure was removed for the Animal Hospital of
the New York Womens League for Animals. Note the fact
of the paved condition of Lafayette Street (left). This
is of recent construction.
About 1900's
Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Assn.
NO REPRODUCTIONS
NEG E 87021
716721f-a.folder: Bond Street & Lafayette Street, Manhattan, NY

720788f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - Bond Street
720788f-a.text:
Lafayette Street (Elm Street), west side, north from and including
Bond (left), to but not including Great Jones Streets, showing construction
work in progress on the Interborough Rapid Transit Co. (I.R.T.) subway,
after the houses which formerly stood there were demolished. The creation
of Lafayette Street became possible as a result of the joining of Elm
Street, hich terminated at a point slightly south of Jersey Street, with
Lafayette Place, rhich comrenced at Great Jones Street. This necessitated
the razing of many buildings which occupied the area between the two
above mentioned streets. The new thoroughfare received its present name
several years later. Also shown is Bond Street, north side, west from
Lafayette Street, to and including Broadway (where it terminates), with
the 5-story Bay State Hotel and Restaurant seen in the extreme left back-
ground, bearing Nos. 663-665 Broadway.
April 2, 1901.
Board of Transportation Photograph.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
Villiam B. Parsons Cullection.
720788f-a.folder: Lafayette Street & Bond Street, Manhattan, NY

720789f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - Bond Street
720789f-a.text:
Lafayette Street (Elm Street), west side, north from Bond (left), to
and including Great Jones Streets, showing construction work in progress
on the Interborough Rapid Transit Co. (I.R.T.) subway after the demolition
of houses which formerly stood there. Lafayette Street was created by the
joining of Elm Street, which terminated at a point slightly south of
Jersey Street with Lafayette Place, which commenced at Great Jones Street.
This necessitated the razing of many buildings which stood between the
above mentioned teo streets. The new thoroughfare was given its present
name several years later.
May 7, 1991.
Board of Transportation Photograph.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
william B. Parsons Collection.
720789f-a.folder: Lafayette Street & Bond Street, Manhattan, NY

720799f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - Bond Street
720799f-a.text:
Lafayette Street, west side, north from and including Bond, to and
including Eaat 4th Streets. Also shown (left foreground) are Nos. 10 and
8 Bond Street, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Lafayette Street.
March 16, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
720799f-a.folder: Lafayette Street & Bond Street, Manhattan, NY

720785f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - Bond Street
720785f-a.text:
Lafayette Street (Elm Street) south from but not including Bond Street,
showing the street as it appears when almost completed, after the demolition
of the houses which formerly stood there. The construction of the street
necessitated the razing of many buildings in a southerly direction from
Lafayette Place, which terminated at Great Jones Street, to Elm Street,
which commenced at a point slightly south of Jersey Street. The new
thoroughfare was named Lafayette Street several years later and under it
was built the Interborough Rapid Transit Co. (I.R.T.) subway.
July 7, 1900.
Board of Transportation Photograph.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
William B. Parsons Collection.
720785f-a.folder: Lafayette Street & Bond Street, Manhattan, NY

720807f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - Bond Street
720807f-a.text:
Lafayette Street (Elm Street), north from but not including Bond Street,
to and including East 8th Street, shouing the street as it appears when
almost completed from Bond to Great Jones Streets (where children are
standing) after the demolition of houses which formerly stood there.
The construction of the street necessitated the razing of many buildings
in a northerly direction from Elm Street, which terminated at a point
slightly south of Jersey Street, to Lafayette Place, which commenced at
Great Jones Street. The new thoroughfare was named Lafayette Street
several years later and under it was constructed the Interborough Rapid
Transit Co. (I.R.T.) subway. In the background is visible the Germania
Theatre, on East 8th Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Fourth Ave.
It was later razed, and on its site now (1937) stands the main building
of the John Wanamaker Department Store.
July 7, 1900.
Board of Transportation Photograph.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
William B. Parsons Collection.
720807f-a.folder: Lafayette Street & Bond Street, Manhattan, NY
